etymologies: Old English thæt, nominative and accusative singular neuter of se ‘the’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch dat and German das

notes.text: The word that can be omitted in standard English where it introduces a subordinate clause, as in she said (that) she was satisfied. It can also be dropped in a relative clause where the subject of the subordinate clause is not the same as the subject of the main clause, as in the book (that) I've just written (‘the book’ and ‘I’ are two different subjects). Where the subject of the subordinate clause and the main clause are the same, use of the word that is obligatory, as in the woman that owns the place (‘the woman’ is the subject of both clauses). It is sometimes argued that, in relative clauses, that should be used for non-human references, while who should be used for human references: a house that overlooks the park but the woman who lives next door. In practice, while it is true to say that who is restricted to human references, the function of that is flexible. It has been used for human and non-human references since at least the 11th century, and is invaluable where both a person and a thing is being referred to, as in a person or thing that is believed to bring bad luck. Is there any difference between the use of that and which in sentences such as any book that gets children reading is worth having, and any book which gets children reading is worth having? The general rule in British English is that, in restrictive relative clauses, where the relative clause serves to define or restrict the reference to the particular one described, which can replace that. However, in non-restrictive relative clauses, where the relative clause serves only to give additional information, that cannot be used: this book, which is set in the last century, is very popular with teenagers but not this book, that is set in the last century, is very popular with teenagers. In US English which is generally used only for non-restrictive relative clauses

definitions: used to identify a specific person or thing observed or heard by the speaker

examples.text: hello, is that Ben?
that's his wife over there

short_definitions: used to identify specific person or thing observed or heard by speaker

definitions: referring to the more distant of two things near to the speaker (the other, if specified, being identified by ‘this’)

examples.text: this is stronger than that

short_definitions: referring to more distant of two things near to speaker

definitions: referring to a specific thing previously mentioned, known, or understood

examples.text: what are we going to do about that?
that's a good idea

short_definitions: referring to specific thing previously mentioned or understood

definitions: used in singling out someone or something and ascribing a distinctive feature to them

examples.text: it is part of human nature to be attracted to that which is aesthetically pleasing
his appearance was that of someone used to sleeping on the streets

short_definitions: used in singling out person or thing and ascribing distinctive feature

definitions: expressing strong agreement with a description just given

examples.text: ‘He's a fussy man.’ ‘He is that.’

short_definitions: expressing strong agreement with description just given

definitions: used instead of ‘which’, ‘who’, ‘whom’, or ‘when’ to introduce a defining clause, especially one essential to identification

examples.text: the book that I've just written
the woman that owns the place
the year that Anna was born

In US English which is generally used only for non-restrictive relative clauses

definitions: used to identify a specific person or thing observed or heard by the speaker

examples.text: how much are those brushes?
look at that chap there

short_definitions: used to identify specific person or thing observed or heard by speaker

definitions: referring to the more distant of two things near to the speaker (the other, if specified, being identified by ‘this’).
short_definitions: referring to more distant of two things near to speaker

definitions: referring to a specific thing previously mentioned, known, or understood

examples.text: seven people died in that incident
he lived in Mysore at that time

short_definitions: referring to specific thing previously mentioned or understood

definitions: used in singling out someone or something and ascribing a distinctive feature to them

examples.text: I have always envied those people who make their own bread

short_definitions: used in singling out person or thing and ascribing distinctive feature

definitions: referring to a specific person or thing assumed as understood or familiar to the person being addressed

examples.text: where is that son of yours?
I let him spend all that money on me
Dad got that hunted look

short_definitions: referring to specific person or thing assumed as understood or familiar to person being addressed

examples.text: I wouldn't go that far

definitions: used with a gesture to indicate size

examples.text: it was that big, perhaps even bigger

short_definitions: used with gesture to indicate size

examples.text: I couldn't get out of the house fast enough, I was that embarrassed!

definitions: introducing a subordinate clause expressing a statement or hypothesis

examples.text: it is possible that we have misunderstood
she said that she was satisfied

short_definitions: introducing subordinate clause expressing statement or hypothesis

examples.text: he seemed pleased that I wanted to continue
she was so tired that she couldn't think

definitions: expressing a purpose, hope, or intention

examples.text: I eat that I may live
we pray that the coming year may be a year of peace
oh that he could be restored to health
